report_title: Lumber & Building Material Stores in the US
executive_summary: Lumber and building material stores have grown alongside growth in housing starts and per capita disposable income. Businesses in the industry retail building materials like lumber, hardwood, cabinets, floor coverings, roofing materials and other building goods. These goods are purchased by professional contractors and consumers engaged in remodeling and construction projects. Rising disposable income has helped ignite remodeling activity, supporting additional demand for lumber and other materials used in home improvement projects.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Mounting External Competition Encouraged Innovation and Consolidation
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Businesses have experienced heightened competition from large home improvement stores. Businesses have had to offer more specialized products and services and loyalty initiatives to stay competitive. Production costs also impact profitability as the price of labor has increased and raw material prices remain volatile. Several businesses have been unable to compete with big-box retailers. Consolidation activity has increased as some larger stores have merged to compete.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue grew in 2020 despite the economic uncertainty
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Revenue grew in 2020 despite the economic uncertainty brought on by the pandemic. Revenue is expected to climb at a CAGR of 1.8% to $145.4 billion through the end of 2024, despite an expected drop of 0.3% in 2024 alone. While heightened interest rates slowed residential construction expansions, stores continued to enjoy growth. Profit has expanded during the period as well.

Stores compete with big-box retailers that offer consumers a one-stop shopping experience. To contend with powerhouses like Lowe's and Home Depot, stores have had to remain price-competitive despite a hike in the price of sawmill lumber. Many minor businesses have shifted their focus to specialized professional contractors that use customizable products, which earn higher profit. Stores have focused on specialty products, including eco-friendly lines, to provide new opportunities.

The industry remains fragmented and many stores operate within a localized area and employ fewer than five people. Consolidation activity has increased as stores aim to compete with big-box retailers and home improvement stores.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Construction activity will climb in the coming years
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Construction activity will climb in the coming years as interest rates drop, which will boost sales for lumber and building material stores. Further growth in disposable income will encourage further growth in sales as consumers invest in home improvement projects. Consumer confidence climbing will also boost large residential construction projects and sales. Revenue is forecast to jump at a CAGR of 1.0% to $152.6 billion through the end of 2029.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Technology and e-commerce play an increasingly important role
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: In addition to offering more specialized product offerings, businesses have started adopting technology for their everyday business practices. Most of this technology focuses on making orders easier and ensuring stores have appropriate stock levels. Technology can also help schedule employees and do payroll. Rising e-commerce trends have continued in recent years, which the pandemic accelerated. Online customer accounts and pricing tools have also been popularized in recent years to encourage repeat purchases.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Upward trends in construction benefitted stores
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Overall growth in construction activity has allowed lumber and building material stores to boost revenue despite fierce competition from big-box retailers. To differentiate themselves from large home improvement stores, lumber and building material stores have added customizable and niche items to their product offerings, including eco-friendly product lines. Projects are typically customized for a house's dimensions and inhabitants' needs. Because these are very important projects, specialty contractors are often enlisted to ensure the project goes smoothly.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Stores have navigated challenges and were provided with opportunities
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Elevated lumber prices led to price-based gains for lumber and building material stores, pushing up revenue. Still, higher prices also may have impacted consumer purchases, potentially reducing sales volumes. The Inflation Reduction Act's extension of tax credits for energy-efficient homes boosted private spending on home improvements, bolstering the plumbing and HVAC equipment segments for lumber and building material stores. Despite slight slowdowns in the residential market because of interest rate hikes, stores did not face considerable declines as DIY residential projects climbed. Also, nonresidential construction markets picking up greatly benefitted lumber and building material stores as the residential construction market cooled off.

industry_definition: This industry consists of stores and dealers (e.g. lumberyards) that retail building materials such as lumber, hardwood, stones and brick. This industry also supplies cabinets, floor coverings, roofing materials, electrical and plumbing goods, doors and windows to the construction market. The industry doesn't include home improvement centers, paint and wallpaper specialty stores or hardware stores.

negative_impact_factors: Low and steady barriers to entry
None and steady level of assistance

key_trends: A store adjusts prices to boost returns while monitoring competitors' pricing. This strategy is vital amid increased competition from home improvement stores, as maintaining low costs is crucial for market position and profitability.

Customizable building products enhance stores' competitive advantage. By catering to the specific needs of contractors and homeowners, these retailers foster loyalty and encourage repeat business across a diverse customer base.

Lumber and building material stores have enjoyed significant growth because of a booming residential construction market and rising lumber prices. The extension of energy-efficient tax credits has also contributed to this expansion trend.

Interest rate cuts will enhance growth for lumber and building material stores. Also, rising consumer confidence will drive increased sales and investment in the construction sector, benefiting these businesses.
Builders FirstSource is a prominent company with over 5.0% market share and a workforce exceeding 28,000 employees. Headquartered in Texas, the company is continuing to expand its operations.

Fragmentation is high among lumber and building material stores. Small stores account for the majority of the market, but the average store generates $2.6 million in revenue and employs around seven workers, limiting the potential for market share growth.

Lumber and building material stores adhere to national labor laws. These regulations encompass minimum wage, mandated breaks and other employee standards to protect workers' rights and ensure fair treatment in the workplace.
Regulations limit credit lines and borrowing to promote equitable access to credit. These laws aim to mitigate discriminatory lending practices and foster a fairer financial landscape for consumers.

Rising purchase costs are significantly impacting revenue and profitability for businesses. Recent price volatility has made it increasingly challenging for companies to maintain consistent profit amid fluctuating expenses.

Wages have seen a slight uptick in tandem with the climb in the minimum wage. Lumber and building materials stores face challenges as these heavy goods require labor-intensive handling and sales processes.

Lumber and building material stores strategically locate near upstream and downstream markets. This positioning helps reduce transportation costs and enhances convenience for consumers and contractors, making procurement more efficient.

The need for building materials is rising in suburban areas near urban centers. Commuting workers buying homes in these regions boost local store sales, highlighting a growing market driven by residential expansion.

Lumber remains a vital product for lumber and building material stores. It's essential for construction projects, but competition has grown with the rise of new materials and eco-friendly alternatives.

Residential construction has surged recently, increasing sales for lumber and building material stores. As construction contractors represent the primary clientele, this trend highlights a booming need within the building materials market.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Many products that lumber and building material stores retail require specific knowledge to properly install and operate, like electrical, plumbing and flooring installations, so licensed tradespeople undertake much of the work. Contractors account for more than half of all revenue for the industry. Also, the specialized and localized nature of the industry appeals to contractors who have specific needs and make frequent purchases.

This segment is composed of two distinct groups, including do-it-for-me (DIFM) customers and DIY customers. The DIFM category includes consumers who purchase materials themselves and hire third parties to complete the projects and installation. This market is more traditional and it has coexisted with the professional market for decades. DIY customers consist of homeowners who purchase new products but complete their own projects and installations. This group of consumers has significantly influenced industry performance in recent years.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Hardware, Lumber and Other Building Materials
products_and_services.product_description: Hardware, lumber and other structural building materials dominate the industry's product mix. Stores focus on providing the highest quality lumber and building materials at competitive prices.

The plumbing, HVAC and electrical supplies product segment is the second-largest source of revenue for lumber and building material stores. Since the largest market for this industry is composed of professional contractors, stores must provide access to a wide suite of supplies to remain competitive in attracting skilled clients.
This product segment includes flooring, floor coverings and various hand tools. This segment also includes a wide variety of other products sold by stores, ranging from key chains to paint.

tier_1_suppliers: Stone, Concrete & Clay Wholesaling in the US
Roofing, Siding & Insulation Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Sawmills & Wood Production in the US
Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: An uptick in housing starts in the United States boosts the performance of lumber and building material stores. As new homes get built, the need for essential construction products—such as lumber, doors and windows—rises significantly. This heightened demand typically translates into increased sales and revenue for these stores, enhancing their growth prospects and overall profitability in the market. Declines in housing starts pose a potential threat to the industry.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has many lumber and building material stores because of the region's high population density, which drives the need for construction and repair services. Frequent severe weather events in the area necessitate ongoing renovations and building projects, bolstering the need for lumber and materials. The Southeast's significant lumber production is crucial, providing nearly half the nation's logging capacity. This abundant supply of raw materials ensures a consistent and affordable inventory for local stores, effectively allowing them to meet regional construction needs.

The West region ranks as the second-largest area for lumber and building material stores because of its strong lumber industry. California dominates this region, boasting the highest number of lumber stores and serving as a pivotal hub for the sector. Proximity to both upstream suppliers and downstream markets enhances the West's appeal for businesses tied to lumber and building materials. This geographic advantage fosters a supportive environment for new and existing companies, promoting growth and establishment in the industry.

Lumber and building material stores concentrate in densely populated areas within the Mid-Atlantic region, particularly New York and New Jersey. These metropolitan hubs serve as vital markets for construction materials. The high demand in these urban centers arises from ongoing residential construction and home renovation projects in surrounding suburban areas. Because of this, stores near major cities benefit from a consistent flow of customers. The concentration of populations in urban environments leads to greater construction activity, reinforcing the importance of lumber and building material retailers in these locations.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Lumber and building material stores must navigate various federal and state regulations that govern employment safety, accessibility, product pricing, competition and environmental impact. The Fair Labor Standards Act stipulates minimum wage and overtime requirements, while OSHA mandates safety protocols to mitigate workplace injuries.

regulations_points.regulation_title: ANTITRUST LAWS: PROTECTING COMPETITION AND FAIR PRICING
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Sherman Act, Wilson Act, Clayton Act and Robinson-Patman Act shape the landscape for lumber and building material stores. These laws prohibit monopolistic practices and price discrimination, fostering a competitive market environment.

The Federal Consumer Credit Protection Act and the Federal Fair Credit Reporting Act impose essential regulations on retailers such as lumber and building material stores. These laws require clear disclosure of financing terms, including APR and total costs, promoting transparency.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Prospective entrants encounter minimal licensing requirements
barriers_points.barrier_description: However, potential competitors must still navigate some governmental regulations that could impact business operations.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Start-up costs pose a significant barrier
barriers_points.barrier_description: High expenses for leasing or purchasing store space and building inventory often deter aspiring businesses from entering the competitive market.

basis_points.basis_description: A store adjusts prices to boost returns while monitoring competitors' pricing.
Maintaining low costs is crucial for market position and profitability amid increased competition from home improvement stores.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Lumber and building material stores exhibit a low level of market share concentration, with only one store controlling more than 5.0% of the market.
Fragmentation is very high among lumber and building material stores. Most lumber and building material stores are privately owned and they supply local and regional markets.
In recent years, many of these small businesses have merged with other stores or exited the industry, increasing concentration.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: High purchasing costs are typical for the retail sector
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: High purchasing costs are typical for the retail sector because stores must maintain a large volume of inventory to sufficiently meet consumer demand. Stores purchase inventory items from a large number of wholesalers, often without long-term contracts.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Retailers unable to charge customers more for products
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: While wholesalers and manufacturers are able to pass material cost increases downstream to buyers, retailers are typically unable to charge customers more for products. Growth in purchasing costs tends to reduce profit for stores.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Store owners absorb most cost increases
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Store owners are forced to absorb most cost increases associated with raw materials used in the goods they sell. Purchases are the largest cost for lumber and building material stores, accounting for more than half of revenue.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Labor costs rank as a primary expense
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Labor costs rank as a primary expense for lumber and building material retailers. Limited digitization among stores means these businesses need a larger inventory management and customer service workforce, raising overall operational costs and complicating entry.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Lumber and building material stores are highly sensitive to the state of the economy. Consumer spending on new residential construction and remodeling typically decreases when economic activity slows.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Fluctuations in Input Prices Have Led to Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Raw material costs significantly impact the performance of lumber and building material stores. When the prices of materials like lumber climb, manufacturers and retailers face challenges in passing those increased costs onto consumers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Innovation is severely limited for stores
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Upstream lumber producers are developing new building materials incorporating alloys and composites. However, many retail stores have yet to integrate these innovative materials into their inventory, limiting options for consumers and builders.

Traditional wood products like planks, boards and plywood remain staples in construction. These materials have a long history and established applications but lack the modern advancements in upstream manufacturing.

FAQs.question: What are the key antitrust laws impacting the lumber and building material stores industry?
FAQs.answer: The Sherman Act, Wilson Act, Clayton Act and Robinson-Patman Act prohibit monopolistic practices and price discrimination, fostering a competitive market environment for lumber and building material stores.

FAQs.question: What are the key federal credit laws impacting retailers like lumber and building material stores?
FAQs.answer: The Federal Consumer Credit Protection Act and the Federal Fair Credit Reporting Act require clear disclosure of financing terms like APR and total costs, promoting transparency for retailers offering financing.

FAQs.question: What assistance does the North American Retail Hardware Association provide to independent hardware retailers?
FAQs.answer: The North American Retail Hardware Association assists independent hardware retailers with brand-specific educational resources, financial management tools and online human resource training to enhance operational efficiency and profitability.

FAQs.question: How do lumber and building material stores differentiate themselves from competition?
FAQs.answer: Some stores have begun expanding their product offerings to include more custom products to stand out from competition by increasing the value provided to clients.

FAQs.question: What are the key factors impacting sales and marketing for lumber and building material stores?
FAQs.answer: Stores generate majority of revenue from new home construction, so sales decline when new home demand drops. Knowledgeable staff helps attract average consumers. Volatile lumber prices and high demand can lead to inventory delays.

FAQs.question: What operational strategies benefit lumber and building material stores?
FAQs.answer: Working directly with manufacturers for lower purchase costs, having solid supplier relationships, retaining talented employees through compensation/benefits (though leading to higher wage costs), and using POS systems to ensure popular products are in stock.

FAQs.question: How does regulation impact the lumber and building material stores industry?
FAQs.answer: Stores must abide by labor laws on treating employees and ensure correct product labeling. Many work with trade associations like NARHA for industry information and training.

FAQs.question: What factors impact profitability for lumber and building material stores?
FAQs.answer: Profit has remained steady alongside increased construction/housing demand. Offering financing can lead to customer payment issues. Exclusive sales contracts with builders reduce demand fluctuation risk. Being located near development/population growth areas maximizes exposure.

FAQs.question: How do lumber and building material stores manage inventory and mitigate lumber price increases?
FAQs.answer: Controlling stock levels to meet demand while avoiding buildup is important. As lumber prices rise, some cost is passed to clients which can negatively impact revenue.

FAQs.question: What trends are impacting product demand for lumber and building material stores?
FAQs.answer: While lumber is the largest segment, many stores diversify into flooring, roofing, cabinets and other residential construction/renovation products to remain competitive with big retailers.

FAQs.question: How do lumber and building material stores monitor residential construction trends?
FAQs.answer: Stores monitor data on new residential construction to ensure being well-positioned to supply builders with needed products for increases in demand.
